_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Tristar North, Inc. - Pasco Facility complies with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) #58 (2017 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is this facility's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local laws/codes.  If an emergency were to occur, it is the facility's policy to notify the Pasco Fire Department as well as Franklin County Emergency Management, as necessary.  Medical emergencies will require notification of the Pasco Fire Department.  This facility has an Emergency Response Plan; however, it does not maintain a trained fire brigade or hazardous material response team on-site to respond to the small initial stages of an emergency.



The Tristar North, Inc. - Pasco Facility is a LPG Transloading facility (specifically, railcar to truck tanker).  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the LPG railcar storage and transloading system only, including the associated piping and storage for up to nine (9) butane railcars (detached).



The Tristar North, Inc. - Pasco Facility complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) accident prevention rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119) and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  This LPG railcar storage and transloading system is designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufacturer's (TRI-FLO Inc.) instructions.  Railcars meet the U.S. Department of Transportation Federal Railroad Administration design requirements for pressurized tank cars.



This is a new facility; therefore, it has never had an accident involving LPG which has resulted in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuation or sheltering in-place.



In the event of an emergency involving the Tristar North, Inc. - Pasco Facility LPG railcar storage and transloading system, it is the policy of the facility to initially con

tact the Pasco Fire Department and request their assistance.  The facility personnel are trained.  The facility emergency action plans are coordinated with Pasco Fire Department and Franklin County Emergency Management.  The Pasco Fire Department is aware of the system and its available fire protection systems (site fire extinguishers, emergency shut-off devices and fire hydrants).  The primary hazardous materials response capabilities are provided by the Pasco Fire Department.



Improvement actions to be considered primarily focus on site security and rail safety measures including continuing safety audits and safety inspections.
